content.text: Once upon a time, in a quiet little village not far from the town of Bremen, there lived an old donkey.
For many years, this donkey had worked hard for his master, carrying heavy loads of grain to the mill and bringing sacks of flour back to the farm.
But now, the donkey was growing old, and his strength was fading.
His master, who was not a kind man, began to grumble that the donkey was no longer useful and spoke of getting rid of him.

The donkey overheard these unkind words and thought to himself, *"If my master no longer wants me, I must find a way to take care of myself."* So, one night, when the moon was high and the farm was silent, the donkey slipped away.
He trotted down the dusty road, his hooves clip-clopping softly, and set off toward the great town of Bremen.
*"There,"* he said to himself, *"I shall become a musician!
I have heard that Bremen has a fine town band, and surely they can use a donkey with a strong voice!"*  As he walked along, the donkey met an old hound lying by the side of the road, panting heavily.
The hound’s ribs showed through his thin fur, and his eyes were sad.
*"Why do you look so weary, my friend?"* asked the donkey kindly. The hound sighed.
*"Ah, I served my master faithfully for many years, hunting and guarding his home.
But now that I am old and my teeth are not as sharp, he says I am no longer good for anything.
He threatened to turn me out—or worse!
So I ran away before he could do me harm."*  The donkey nodded thoughtfully. *"Come with me to Bremen!
I am going there to become a musician.
You have a fine, deep bark—surely you can join the town band too!"*  The hound’s tail wagged weakly.
*"That sounds like a splendid idea!"* he said, and together, the two new friends continued down the road.
Before long, they came upon an old cat sitting on a fence, licking her paws with a very grumpy expression.
Her fur was matted, and her whiskers drooped. *"Good day, madam,"* said the donkey politely.
*"Why do you look so cross?"*  The cat flicked her tail. *"Cross? I should think so!
My mistress used to love me, but now that I am old and cannot catch mice as I once did, she says I am useless.
She even threatened to drown me in the river!
So I ran away before she could carry out her cruel plan."*  The donkey and the hound exchanged glances.
*"That is no way to treat such a fine cat,"* said the hound. *"Come with us to Bremen!
We are going to become musicians.
You have a lovely voice—surely you can sing in the town band!"*  The cat’s ears perked up.
*"A musician, you say?
Well, I *do* have a very fine meow."* And with that, she leaped down from the fence and joined the growing group.
The three friends walked on until they reached a farmyard, where they heard a loud, angry voice shouting, *"Shoo!
Get out of here, you worthless bird!"* They looked up and saw an old rooster perched on a fence, flapping his wings in distress.
His feathers were ruffled, and he looked very tired. *"What is the matter, my fine fellow?"* asked the donkey.
The rooster sighed. *"My master says that tomorrow he will have me made into soup!
He says I no longer crow loudly enough to wake him in the morning.
But I do not want to end up in a pot!
So I flew away as fast as I could."*  The donkey smiled. *"Then you must come with us!
We are going to Bremen to become musicians.
You have a powerful voice—surely you can sing in the town band!"*  The rooster puffed out his chest proudly.
*"Indeed I can!
My crow is the finest in the land!"* And with that, he fluttered down to join the others.
Now the four friends—donkey, hound, cat, and rooster—walked together toward Bremen.
But as the sun began to set, they realized they would not reach the town before nightfall.
*"We must find a place to rest,"* said the donkey.
*"Tomorrow, we shall continue our journey."*  Just then, they saw a small cottage in the distance, with a warm light glowing in the window.
*"Perhaps the people inside will let us stay the night,"* said the cat.
But as they drew closer, they noticed something strange.
The cottage was dark and quiet, but through the window, they could see a table set with food and drink—and four rough-looking men sitting around it, counting piles of gold.
*"Those are robbers!"* whispered the hound. *"And they have stolen that treasure!"*  The donkey had an idea.
*"We must scare them away so we can spend the night in safety.

Let us stand on each other’s backs and make a terrible noise!"*  The others agreed, and so they stacked themselves up: the donkey at the bottom, the hound on his back, the cat on the hound’s back, and the rooster perched on top.
Then, all at once, they began to make their loudest sounds—the donkey brayed, the hound barked, the cat yowled, and the rooster crowed with all his might.
The robbers inside jumped up in terror, thinking a terrible monster had come to attack them.
*"Run for your lives!"* they shouted, and they fled into the night, leaving the cottage and their treasure behind.
The four friends laughed with delight.
They climbed down from their tower and went inside, where they found a fine supper waiting.
The donkey ate some hay, the hound gnawed on a bone, the cat lapped up some milk, and the rooster pecked at some grain.
Then, tired from their long journey, they curled up in the cozy cottage and fell fast asleep.
Meanwhile, the robbers had stopped in the woods to catch their breath.
*"What was that dreadful noise?"* one of them asked.
*"I do not know,"* said another, *"but I am not going back to find out!"*  But the boldest of the robbers, who was also the greediest, said, *"I will go back and see what is happening.
If the coast is clear, I will signal to you."*  So he crept back to the cottage and peeked through the window.
In the dim light, he saw the cat’s glowing eyes and thought they were fiery coals.
He reached out to light his pipe, but the cat, thinking he was attacking her, leaped at his face and scratched him fiercely.
The robber screamed and ran out the door, but the hound, who had been dozing nearby, bit his leg.
The donkey, startled awake, kicked him with his strong hind legs, and the rooster, perched on the roof, crowed loudly in his ear.
The robber ran as fast as he could, howling in fear. *"Help! Help!

There is a witch in the cottage with fiery eyes, a man with a knife is stabbing me, a giant is beating me, and a judge is shouting at me from the roof!"*  The other robbers, hearing his cries, did not wait to find out what had happened.
They ran away as fast as they could, never to return.
The four friends, now safe and sound, decided to stay in the cottage.
They lived there happily for many years, making music together and enjoying their new home.
And though they never did reach Bremen, they agreed that they had found something even better—a place where they were loved, safe, and free.
And so, the donkey, the hound, the cat, and the rooster lived out their days in peace, proving that even when the world seems unkind, friendship and cleverness can lead to a happy ending.
